titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the John Calmann Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Friday January 4, 2019 at 08:08

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of writings, correspondence, and diaries documenting John Calmann's career and life as a gay man in Britain at a time of changing attitudes towards homosexuality.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Sir John Riddell, 2006. Gift of Christopher Phillips, 2010.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator in the original accession. Copyright for Accession 2011-M-016 is retained by Christopher Phillips throughout his lifetime, after which it passes to Yale University. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: John Calmann Papers (MS 1857). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The material is arranged in two series and one addition: Series 1. Writings, 1945-1973; Series II. Personal and Correspondence, 1943-1987.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p:
John Calmann (né Hans Rudolf Calmann), was born in Hamburg, Germany, on December 6, 1935. The son of a Jewish father, he emigrated with his family to England in March 1937, first to Horspath and later to London. Calmann was educated at the village school at Horspath, the Dragon School in Oxford, Arnold House School in London, Westminster School, and at Christ Church, University of Oxford. He took his degree in history in 1957 and then studied for a B.Litt. degree at St. Anthony's College, but did not receive it.
From 1959 to 1960 John Calmann lived in New York under Benjamin Sonnenberg's (his mentor) aegis and worked as a journalist for The Wall Street Journal . During this time he wrote many of the letters published in the book The Letters of John Calmann, 1951-1980 . He then returned to his parents' home, Perridge House in Pilton, where he completed a novel in 1961. From 1962 to 1963 he worked in Luxembourg as an international civil servant. Back in England, he edited The Times supplement Opera Mundi — Europe from 1963 to 1965. From 1965 to 1966 he worked for the Institute for Strategic Studies and wrote A Handbook of Western Europe . In 1967 he joined the publishing house of Paul Elek, and he became a candidate for the Liberal Party for the Hampstead section of London. In 1969 he joined the Phaidon Press. In 1975 he established his own co-edition publishing firm, Blacker, Calmann & Cooper (later John Calmann & Cooper, John Calmann & King and Calmann & King).
On April 26, 1980, Calmann was murdered by a hitchhiker near Bollène, France.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The original accession, Series I and II, is open for research.

Accession 2011-M-016 contains material restricted by the donor. Access to this accession requires the written permission of Christopher Phillips until August 29, 2029, after which access is unrestricted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of writings, correspondence, and diaries documenting John Calmann's career and life as a gay man in Britain at a time of changing attitudes towards homosexuality.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series is arranged alphabetically and includes articles, book reviews, editorials, essays, plays, novels, and poetry. It is likely that some of the writings are unpublished.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

did.unittitle: Baron de Montesquieu and Proust [article; proofs and several drafts]
Caravaggio and Italian Painting in the 17th Century
The Common Market [draft synopses and related materials]
Cooperation in Arms Procurement in Western Europe (Internal I.S.S. Document)
Essays for Opera Mundi [12; also plans for a guide to London]
The Growth of the Idea of European Unity [synopsis and outline]
Notes on Pictures, or, A Very Bad Fragment
Poems and Truth from my Life [notebook]
The Price He Had to Pay [play]
Things Seen: Opera Tableaux and the Old Masters
Verbatim Report of Interview between Mr. Heath...and M. Charles Ronsac

accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

odd.head: General
odd.p: There is no extant notebook #3 for the period covering March 24, 1958-October 11, 1959.
